title: Error: could not decrypt key with given passphrase
body:
Hi there,

WARN [07-25|18:26:38.681] Served eth_signTransaction               conn=82.196.0.91:50700    reqid=455 t=24.863µs     err="authentication needed: password or unlock"
#### System information

Geth version: `1.9.1`
OS & Version:Linux
Commit hash : (if `develop`)

There are a lot of logs below.
```
7:57.129] Served eth_signTransaction               conn=82.196.0.91:50700    reqid=427 t=13.431µs     err="authentication needed: password or unlock"
WARN [07-25|18:27:57.129] Served eth_signTransaction               conn=82.196.0.91:50700    reqid=428 t=14.471µs     err="authentication needed: password or unlock"

WARN [07-25|18:27:57.130] Served eth_signTransaction               conn=82.196.0.91:50700    reqid=460 t=13.017µs     err="authenticati
```
What's the meaning of this?

You exposed your RPC to the internet and somebody is trying to actively break your account and move your funds. Why would you run in `insecure` mode? You explicitly allowed with via a command line flag.
Ah, I think it's not unlock, only that is forbidden. Still, please close your RPC immediately for remote access.
Somebody is trying to move your funds, waiting for you to accidentally unlock, so they can execute their transaction.
Thank you. What should I say about my - rpcaddr parameter? I want to include 10.0.0.1-10.0.0.16

It's not possible. TCP doesn't work like that. You either open the port in a way that only localhost can access it (default), or you open the port in a way that everyone can access it. If you need to restrict access, you need to do that yourself either via a firewall (easy to mess up), or ideally put a custom proxy program between geth and your external application that can properly authenticate requests. Geth is not meant to be a public node, it's meant to be a local, private gateway, that only local private applications can access.
I changed to Intranet. 0.0.0.0 to 10.0.0.13,Why do I still have these logs?

[07-25|18:55:59.066] Served eth_signTransaction               conn=82.196.0.91:48552    reqid=301 t=26.222µs    err="authentication needed: password or unlock"

Because that's not how TCP works. The address you specify is the interface you want to listen on, it can be localhost, or can be anything (0.0.0.0) or it can be a specific network card. You are specifying the hardware you are accepting connections on, TCP has no notion of filtering the source. Whoever can reach your hardware can access your port.

so whats a proper configuration, for geth startup? Want RPC ports open for frontend but don't want others to gain access

using geth + open-ethereum-pool , which uses go-ethereum under the hood

currently using
geth --syncmode fast --cache=4096 --rpc --mine --rpcaddr 0.0.0.0 --rpcport "8545"

> so whats a proper configuration, for geth startup? Want RPC ports open for frontend but don't want others to gain access

That totally depends on your local network setup and your requirements. Does the node sit on a local network? Then `0.0.0.0` should be fine -- assuming you trust the other participants on the local network. Does it sit on internet? Is there a router that reroutes the external IP to the internal -- then you're basically exposing it to the internet again. 

Since geth cannot/does not do IP filtering, you can (on linux) use e.g. `iptables` to whitelist certain ip-addresses which are allowed to talk to your node. A nicer way to handle `iptables` is via `ufw`, which provides easier configuraton than raw `iptables`. 

Like any network-connected applications, setting up a geth node securely requires a bit of knowledge about networking and routing, and it's difficult to give a generic answer to how to properly set it up -- it totally depends on several things that are not in geth's domain.
@holiman it is a VPS. Seems the biggest concerns are just the log file and in bound traffic if no Ethereum address is being used on the server.
